Comment: Keres opens with P-K4, an opening that usually leads to a fast-moving, tactical game.
Arlamowski intends to play a Caro-Kann in response.
Instead of playing P-Q4 at once, Keres decides to develop his QN.
Arlamowski ignores the unusual move order and plays his intended second move.
Keres decides against 3 P-Q4, which would transpose into the 3 N-QB3 variation of the Caro-Kann, and develops his other Knight.
Arlamowski initiates an exchange of central Pawns...
With Keres having 2 pieces already developed, Arlamowski decides he'd better start developing his own.
...which Arlamowski unaccountably falls directly into. He failed to ask the question: why would Keres block his own KB with a seemingly useless Queen move?
That's why! Nicely done by Keres, with help from his oblivious opponent.
